description: R3 develop a distributed-ledger platform, Corda, which has both an open-source and enterprise offering (I worked on both).

During my time at R3, I was placed in two teams: Corda Enterprise Network Manager (CENM) and Kernel. In both teams, my primary responsibility was to develop bug fixes in Kotlin, often utilising dev tools such as Azure, Kubernetes, Docker and Gradle. The bugs I tackled were typically related to Corda Firewall, the database migration tool and logging.

In addition, I was involved in reviewing and approving code commits made by other developers which affected areas of the codebase that I'd worked on. I also carried out research and produced a report for R3's executive committee into another blockchain platform, Quorum. This focused on its open-sources libraries and use of Zero-Knowledge Proofs (ZKPs).

One of the most enjoyable tasks was R3's "Internship Academy". This consisted of a day spent with other interns (virtually) to research and pitch companies to the executive committee as to whom sales should target. It was a great collaborative experience with the chance to meet individuals from across the company.

Another opportunity I took part in was R3's Engineering Hackathon. Engineers were randomly put into groups and tasked with developing a game on Corda within 48 hours. My team's idea was to develop CordShips - Battleships on Corda and I developed the API to facilitate communication between the frontend and Corda. I was extremely proud of the team effort and we won best overall!

I was selected to take part in Hack Cambridge 2020. My idea was centred around environmental sustainability; to create a system which allowed users to track their energy wastage in their home and learn from this to automatically make adjustments. I divided my team (4 members) in half - specialising in hardware and software. The hardware team focused on using an Arduino, various sensors (light, heat, sound, movement) to determine the state of a room and actuators in order to make adjustments.
They recorded the state of the room, adding this data to a database hosted on AWS and created an interface to control the lights and heating.

I focused on developing both the front and back end of the web application; creating both a UI for the user to visually see their energy usage and energy wastage (in essence determined by when energy is consumed and there is no activity) and interpreting data to determine if an action should be taken. Based on the previous history and the state of the current room, if there was minimal activity, a request would be made to the hardware interface to turn off the lights and reduce the heating. Through the web app, users could also manually make adjustments remotely.
Overall, it was a great opportunity and challenge; with many technical challenges occurring and overcome. Not only this, it was great to work effectively in a team with like-minded individuals.
Since 2019, I've been a Student Partner at Warwick for Microsoft. This has allowed me to become apart of an extremely talented community and represent Microsoft on campus.

As part of the program, I've had the opportunity to put on and participate in events. The most recent event I was involved in was "IoT on Azure" - presenting how Azure can be used to provide a backend for IoT devices in addition to managing and controlling them.

I've also been able to help other students develop their technical understanding through workshops and increase awareness of Microsoft related products. Not only has this been a great way to improve my own technical skills but it's also helped my communication skills, particularly in regards to explaining a problem and discussing a potential solution.

Furthermore, the program has given me access to a wealth of Microsoft resources - including Azure. With cloud computing becoming increasingly the norm, gaining access to such resources is crucial to keep relevant with the skillset that employers desire. It's extremely useful to have the ability to spin up a remote virtual machine to assist with projects!

I'm looking forward to continuing the role in my 3rd year and exploring more of the opportunities that the program has to offer. It's a great program and I'd recommend it to anyone who's considering it.

SourceChain is an online recruitment platform. In 2019, they were looking to expand their customer base to Germany. My role consisted of creating a target market contact list containing senior individuals at relevant companies.

The majority of my work consisted of utilising LinkedIn Recruiter. I believed the task was easily automatable, therefore, in my spare time, I developed a Chrome extension; Scraper. Presented with a search result on LinkedIn Recruiter, with the press of a button, Scraper intelligently collected the desired data from each profile and copied it to the clipboard in a friendly format; allowing it to be pasted directly into a spreadsheet. This allowed me to complete the task far faster than if I had manually completed it.
SourceChain requested to use Scraper for themselves before I left.

Upon completion, the target market contact list consisted of over 8,000 entries of relevant individuals that they could target. In addition, for each entry, I provided a best guess at the individual's email addresses based on the email formats used by the company.
I was also involved in another project for a sister company, which required me to maintain and update the contents of a WordPress site. This was a great opportunity to become involved with a startup.
This was my first formal role, however, I was given a lot of scope to work on tasks which were not only engaging but of relevance to my interests.

My primary responsibility was to support departments in their administrative and technical requirements. This included researching and purchasing equipment, filing and archiving documents and assisting colleagues with their IT issues.

It also gave me the opportunity to essentially act as an IT consultant - assessing their current IT practises and suggesting how they could be improved. For example, I proposed and then successfully migrated their client file log from a spreadsheet to a database. Not only was this solution more efficient, but it also increased usability by facilitating forms and reports (utilising VBA and SQL).

Another project in which I was involved with was updating the company website. This had just been relaunched, therefore, I was involved in uploading and maintaining content and analysing traffic using Google Analytics.

I was also involved in increasing both employee and customer awareness regarding GDPR for HR. This took the form of conducting research, producing presentations and then updating company policy documentation.
